Platform.Title: [E_coli_2] Affymetrix E. coli Genome 2.0 Array
Platform.Description:
Affymetrix submissions are typically submitted to GEO using the GEOarchive method described at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/geo/info/geo_affy.html
The GeneChipÂ® E. coli Genome 2.0 Array contains probe sets to detect transcripts from the K12 strain of E. coli and three pathogenic strains of E. coli. Using the new E. coli Genome 2.0 Array, researchers can gain a comprehensive view of three pathogenic forms of E. coli while continuing ongoing research projects with the K12 strain.
The GeneChip E. coli Genome 2.0 Array includes approximately 10,000 probe sets for all 20,366 genes present in four strains of E. coli. Due to the high degree of similarity between the E. coli strains, whenever possible, a single probe set is tiled to represent the equivalent ortholog in all four strains. The GeneChip E. coli Genome 2.0 Array tiles probe sets over the entire open reading frame (ORF) of E. coli, includes over 700 intergenic regions, probes for various antibiotic resistance markers, and incorporates additional control and reporter genes from the previous generation E. coli array.

Column.Name: Species Scientific Name
Column.Description: The genus and species of the organism represented by the probe set.

Column.Name: Annotation Date
Column.Description: The date that the annotations for this probe array were last updated. It will generally be earlier than the date when the annotations were posted on the Affymetrix web site.

Column.Name: Sequence Type
Column.Description: Indicates whether the sequence is an Exemplar, Consensus or Control sequence. An Exemplar is a single nucleotide sequence taken directly from a public database. This sequence could be an mRNA or EST. A Consensus sequence, is a nucleotide sequence assembled by Affymetrix, based on one or more sequence taken from a public database.

Column.Name: Representative Public ID
Column.Description: The accession number of a representative sequence. Note that for consensus-based probe sets, the representative sequence is only one of several sequences (sequence sub-clusters) used to build the consensus sequence and it is not directly used to derive the probe sequences. The representative sequence is chosen during array design as a sequence that is best associated with the transcribed region being interrogated by the probe set. Refer to the "Sequence Source" field to determine the database used.

Column.Name: Sequence Source
Column.Description: The database from which the sequence used to design this probe set was taken.

Column.Name: Target Description
Column.Description: GenBank description associated with the representative public identifier. Blank for some probe sets.

Column.Name: Gene Title
Column.Description: Title of Gene represented by the probe set.

Column.Name: Gene Symbol
Column.Description: A gene symbol, when one is available (from UniGene).

Column.Name: Gene Ontology Biological Process
Column.Description: Gene Ontology Consortium Biological Process derived from LocusLink. Each annotation consists of three parts: "Accession Number // Description // Evidence". The description corresponds directly to the GO ID. The evidence can be "direct", or "extended".

Column.Name: Gene Ontology Cellular Component
Column.Description: Gene Ontology Consortium Cellular Component derived from LocusLink. Each annotation consists of three parts: "Accession Number // Description // Evidence". The description corresponds directly to the GO ID. The evidence can be "direct", or "extended".

Column.Name: Gene Ontology Molecular Function
Column.Description: Gene Ontology Consortium Molecular Function derived from LocusLink. Each annotation consists of three parts: "Accession Number // Description // Evidence". The description corresponds directly to the GO ID. The evidence can be "direct", or "extended".

Platform.Title: Affymetrix Custom Array - enterocha520147F
Platform.Organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2
Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655
Platform.Manufacture-Protocol: Array with 511706 features, in 1 zones, with 24826 biosequences representing 254179 reporters and 24826 composite sequences, with surface type unknown
Platform.Description: This array is designed for use with the 7 listed genomes. Associated with each Series is a supplementary filter file that was used for data analysis. The filter file contains only the probeset ID's for the associated Samples.

Sample.Title: Ecoli WT +ile rep2

Channel.Source: E. coli wild-type, replete isoleucine, control
Channel.Organism: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655
Channel.Treatment-Protocol: Cells were allowed to starve for isoleucine in medium containing 60 uM ile.
Channel.Growth-Protocol: Cells were grown in a fermentor with constant O2 saturation and pH was maintained at 7.4. Growth medium was MOPS+glucose+20 AAs (as described by Wanner 1977). Replete isoleucine was 400 um; isoleucine starvation was with 60 uM. For wildtype, ile replete control, total RNA was extracted in log phase (OD600 of ~0.4). For ile starved wt and mutants, total RNA was extracted from cells ~40 min after growth arrest.
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Qiagen RNeasy kit extraction with optional DNase step
Channel.Label: biotin
Channel.Label-Protocol: RNA converted to cDNA by random-hexamer primed first strand synthesis with Superscript II and biotinylated with Roche Enzo kit according to Affymetrix protocol.

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Hybridization was at 60 degrees C for 16 h according to Affymetrix protocol ProkGE_WS2v2-450.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: Affymetrix GCOS scanner software and GeneChip Scanner 3000.
Sample.Data-Processing: RMA with quartile normalization according to method of Irizarry et al, 2003. The raw .cel files were processed in RMA using Bioconductor R package: affy Version:1.8.1 Date:2005-09-03, with the option Filter.genes corresponding to the MG1655 subset of probesets from the arrays, as reflected in the sample files. Replicates were averaged for ratio calculations. Ratio calculations are provided in the supplementary files on the Series record.

Column.Name: VALUE
Column.Description: Values are log2 intensities normalized by RMA.

Sample.Title: Ecoli crp -ile rep1

Channel.Organism: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655
Channel.Treatment-Protocol: Cells were allowed to starve for isoleucine in medium containing 60 uM ile.
Channel.Growth-Protocol: Cultures were grown in a fermentor with constant O2 saturation and pH was maintained at 7.4. Growth medium was MOPS+glucose+20 AAs (as described by Wanner 1977). Replete isoleucine was 400 um; isoleucine starvation was with 60 uM. The control was wildtype grown with replete ile from which total RNA was extracted in log phase (OD600 of ~0.4). For ile starved wt and mutants, total RNA was extracted ~40 min after growth arrest.
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Qiagen RNeasy kit extraction with optional DNase step
Channel.Label: biotin
Channel.Label-Protocol: RNA converted to cDNA by random-hexamer primed first strand synthesis with Superscript II and biotinylated with Roche Enzo kit according to Affymetrix protocol.

Sample.Scan-Protocol: Affymetrix GCOS scanner software and GeneChip Scanner 3000.
Sample.Data-Processing: RMA with quartile normalization according to method of Irizarry et al, 2003. The raw .cel files were processed in RMA using Bioconductor R package: affy Version:1.8.1 Date:2005-09-03, with the option Filter.genes corresponding to the MG1655 subset of probesets from the arrays, as reflected in the sample files. Replicates were averaged for ratio calculations. Ratio calculations are provided in the supplementary files on the Series record.

Sample.Title: WT_+ile_rep1

Channel.Source: E. coli wild-type, replete isoleucine, control
Channel.Organism: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655
Channel.Treatment-Protocol: Cells were allowed to starve for isoleucine in medium containing 60 uM ile.
Channel.Growth-Protocol: Cultures were grown in a fermentor with constant O2 saturation and pH was maintained at 7.4. Growth medium was MOPS+glucose+20 AAs (as described by Wanner 1977). Replete isoleucine was 400 um; isoleucine starvation was with 60 uM. The control was wildtype grown with replete ile from which total RNA was extracted in log phase (OD600 of ~0.4). For ile starved wt and mutants, total RNA was extracted ~40 min after growth arrest.
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Qiagen RNeasy kit extraction with optional DNase step
Channel.Label: biotin
Channel.Label-Protocol: RNA converted to cDNA by random-hexamer primed first strand synthesis with Superscript II and biotinylated with Roche Enzo kit according to Affymetrix protocol.

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Hybridization was at 60 degrees C for 16 h according to Affymetrix protocol ProkGE_WS2v2-450.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: Affymetrix GCOS scanner software and GeneChip Scanner 3000.
Sample.Data-Processing: RMA with quartile normalization according to method of Irizarry et al, 2003. The raw .cel files were processed in RMA using Bioconductor R package: affy Version:1.8.1 Date:2005-09-03, with the option Filter.genes corresponding to the MG1655 subset of probesets from the arrays, as reflected in the sample files. Replicates were averaged for ratio calculations. Ratio calculations are provided in the supplementary files on the Series record. For GPL3154, the probeset filter file was created by parsing Affymetrix E_coli_2.na29.annot.csv file (create_date=2009-06-30 PDT 20:45:08): 1. Selected all MG1655 locustags from Transcript ID(Array Design) (4070 locustags). 2. Selected all IG intergenic regions from Transcript ID(Array Design) (1297 Igs). 3. Manually selected based on NC_000913 alignment value (250 locustags).

Series.Title: E. coli Isoleucine starvation and stringent response network
Series.Summary: Transcription profiling of wild type, relA-, and relA-spoT-, crp-, dksA-, rpoS-, lrp- mutant strains of E. coli starved for isoleucine Bacteria comprehensively reorganize their global gene expression when faced with nutrient exhaustion. In Escherichia coli and other free-living bacteria, the alarmone ppGpp facilitates this massive response by directly or indirectly coordinating the down-regulation of genes of the translation apparatus, and the induction of biosynthetic genes and the general stress response. Such a large reorientation likely requires the cooperative activities of many different genetic regulators, yet the structure of the transcription network below the level of ppGpp remains poorly defined. Using isoleucine starvation as an experimental model system for amino acid starvation, we identified genes that required ppGpp, Lrp, and RpoS for their induction. Surprisingly, despite the fact that the overwhelming majority of genes controlled by Lrp and RpoS required ppGpp for their activation, we found that these two regulons were not induced simultaneously. The data reported here suggest that metabolic genes, such as those of the Lrp regulon, require only a low basal level of ppGpp for their efficient induction. In contrast, the RpoS-dependent general stress response is not robustly induced until relatively high levels of ppGpp accumulate. Here we describe a data-driven conceptual model that explains how bacterial cells allocate transcriptional resources between metabolic and stress survival processes by discretely tuning regulatory activities to a central indicator of cellular physiology. The regulatory structure that emerges is consistent with a rheostatic model of the stringent response that allows cells to efficiently adapt to a wide range of nutritional environments. Keywords: genetic modification design; stress response; isoleucine starvation
Series.Overall-Design: Two experiments were run. First experiment: WT and several mutant strains were starved for isoleucine (exhaustion of 60 uM ile). 40 minutes after starvation, RNA was extracted. All samples were compared to RNA from rapidly growing WT cells in identical medium replete with isoleucine (400 uM). 16 samples were hybridized: duplicates of 8 strains/conditions. Wildtype in log phase (OD = 0.4) with replete ile was control for ile starved samples. Second experiment: WT strain was starved for isoleucine (exhaustion of 60 uM ile). RNA was extracted at 12 timepoints as the cells entered stationary phase. All samples were compared to RNA from rapidly growing WT cells in identical medium replete with isoleucine (400 uM). 14 samples were hybridized: duplicates of the control condition and single timepoints during starvation. Wildtype in log phase (OD = 0.4) with replete ile was control for ile starved samples.

Column.Name: PROBESETS
Column.Description: Affymetrix probeset name in array description file

Column.Name: WT
Column.Description: log2 ratio of averaged replicates of WT_ILE*/E-COLI*

Column.Name: relA
Column.Description: log2 ratio of averaged replicates of RELA_*_ILE/E-COLI*

Column.Name: relAspoT
Column.Description: log2 ratio of averaged replicates of RELASPOT_*_ILE/E-COLI*
